ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned more about a number of topics in (mostly) contemporary epistemology, including several that I hadn't known about before: the contrast between conservatism and evidentialism, for instance. The course does a good job of picking slightly oddball topics that end up giving you a nice picture of the state the field.
Excellent class that raises questions fundamental to knowledge (what it is, how we know if we have it, what to do in the face of peer disagreement.)

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: great handouts, very reasonable reading load. Weaknesses: should have been more emphasis on writing midterm was a test, and the longest paper was 8 pages max. Not enough writing to really develop one's views on the material.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This is an interesting course if you give it the chance to be. If you're willing to engage with the material, actually do the readings (which are not long at all), and pay attention in lecture, you'll like it if you like philosophy. Interesting and thought-provoking.

Would recommend to people who already have an investment in the material due to a background in philosophy or related disciplines. I could see how the discussions might appear irrelevant or inside basebally to those who haven't seen much philosophy before.
This was a really interesting course, intellectually engaging but not too taxing, and Professor DeRose is great.
I think this is a good introduction to Epistemology and the content of the course is applicable beyond philosophy--I took it as a CogSci major and found that there were interesting overlaps.
